bibl.title: Military Orders for Robert P. Cooke and Alexander N. Stark, November 10, 1900

div1.p: Special Orders #265 annuls Cooke's contract as acting assistant surgeon for the U. S. Army. Extension to Stark's leave of absence is granted. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Military Orders for Robert P. Cooke and Alexander N. Stark, November 10, 1900
div1.p:
FROM THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Spec Orders Vol 2
1900
Cooke - Stark

SPECIAL ORDERS, }
No. 265 }

HEADQUARTERS OF THE ARMY,
ADJUTANT GENERAL'S OFFICE,
Washington, November 10, 1900.

1. By direction of the Secretary of War, 1st Class Sergeant
Harry W. Chadwick, Signal Corps, Signal Corps Post, Fort
Myer, Virginia, is transferred to Fort Sill, Oklahoma Terri-
tory. He will be sent to that station and will report upon
arrival to the commanding officer for duty and by letter to the
signal officer, Department of the Missouri, Omaha, Nebraska.

2. By direction of the Secretary of War, Sergeant Joseph
Marthens, Signal Corps, now at Fort Sill, Oklahoma Territory,
when relieved by 1st Class Sergeant Chadwick will be sent to
San Francisco, California, reporting upon arrival to the com-
manding general. Department of California, for transportation
to Manila, Philippine Islands. Upon arrival at Manila he will
report to the commanding general, Division of the Philippines,
for assignment to duty.

3. By direction of the Secretary of War, the following-
named enlisted men, now at the stations designated after their
respective names, will be discharged from the Army, by way
of favor, by the commanding officers of their respective sta-
tions:

Private Waldo E. Doré, Troop A, 2d Cavalry, Matanzas,
Cuba;

Private Joseph E. Cosgrove, Troop H, 7th Cavalry, Havana,
Cuba.
These soldiers are not entitled to travel-pay.

4. By direction of the Secretary of War, Corporal Urman
S. Lodge and 1st Class Private George C. Turner, Signal Corps,
Governors Island, New York, are transferred to Manila, Phil-
ippine Islands. They will be sent on the transport “Kilpat-
rick” to that station and will report upon arrival to the chief
signal officer, Division of the Philippines, for assignment to
duty.

5. By direction of the Secretary of War, Corporal Harry H.
Harman and 2d Class Private Thomas D. Smith, Signal Corps,
Signal Corps Post, Fort Myer, Virginia, are transferred to
Governors Island, New York. They will be sent to that sta-
impracticable for these soldiers to carry rations of any kind.
Upon expiration of leave they will report to the commanding
officer, Fort Columbus, New York, who will furnish them
transportation to their station.

10. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, the fol-
lowing-named acting assistant surgeons, U. S. Army, are re-
lieved from duty in the Division of Cuba, and will proceed to
the places hereinafter specified and report as indicated:

Timothy F. Goulding, to Washington, District of Colum-
bia, and report in person to the Surgeon General of the Army
for instructions.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

11. The travel performed by Captain William C. Borden,
assistant surgeon, U. S. Army, November 7 to 9, 1900, from
this city to Fort Monroe, Virginia, and return, on official busi-
ness pertaining to the Medical Department, is approved by
the Acting Secretary of War as having been necessary for the
public service, the urgency of the duty having been such as to
prevent his obtaining orders in advance.

12. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, the exten-
sion of leave of absence granted Captain Alexander N. Stark,
assistant surgeon, U. S. Army, in Special Orders, No. 227,
September 27, 1900, from this office, is further extended to in-
clude October 29, 1900.
✓

13. By direction of the Acting Secretary of War, 2d Lieu-
tenant William Swift Martin (now serving as private, Troop
M, 1st U. S. Cavalry), recently appointed in the Infantry arm
of the service, with rank from October 11, 1900, is assigned to
the 1st U. S. Infantry. Upon accepting his commission he will
be assigned by his regimental commander to a company of the
1st U. S. Infantry serving in the Division of the Philippines,
and will proceed to join that company. The travel enjoined
is necessary for the public service.
